Comment: The Trump administration said in documents filed in federal court Tuesday that it has engaged in “appropriate diplomatic discussions” with El Salvador concerning Kilmar Abrego García, the Maryland resident who was illegally deported to the Central American country last month and is still being held in prison there.  What “appropriate diplomatic discussions” meant, however, was not made clear in the Justice Department document, which was filed during a discovery process now underway after an appeals court excoriated the administration for its apparent lack of effort to abide by a U.S. district court judge’s orders to facilitate Abrego García’s return. On Tuesday, the State Department declined to offer any details.  “We do not comment on private-diplomatic discussions and have nothing to share at this time,” a State Department spokesperson said in a statement.  Read more here: [https://www.washingtonpost.com/immigration/2025/04/22/kilmar-abrego-garcia-el-salvador/?utm\_campaign=wp\_main&utm\_medium=social&utm\_source=reddit.com](https://www.washingtonpost.com/immigration/2025/04/22/kilmar-abrego-garcia-el-salvador/?utm_campaign=wp_main&utm_medium=social&utm_source=reddit.com)
Author: washingtonpost

Comment: Technically, the Trump admin probably doesn't even have to bring him back.  He had an order of deportation, but a stay from being deported to El Salvador.  That means, to my understanding, that he could be deported to anywhere without a further court order as long as that place was not El Salvador.  To be sent to El Salvador, the admin would need to return to court and prove that the circumstances in which the stay was granted no longer apply.  They didn't do that step and that is how/why he was denied due process.  However, this doesn't prevent them from sending him to, for instance, Venezuela without further hearing.  So, it would not surprise me to hear that the Trump admin took him and then just sent him directly to another country to be deported.  Alternatively, I guess they could bring him back to the US and incarcerate him where they would argue at a bond hearing once again that he's a member of MS13 and a danger to the community and cannot be released.  Then they'd expedite a hearing to prove that the situation in El Salvador has changed and the court might lift his stay and they send him right back to CECOT.  Of course, the horrible part of this is that anyone can just be sent to a maximum security prison/death camp despite their only crime being coming to a country without documentation in an attempt to have a better and safer life.
